ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Professor Dang also provided short additional recorded lectures for supplementary information.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I just learned so much about the history of Black freedom movements and the different forms they took. I learned about my own prejudice and how to unlearn that. I learned about how to be an honest and respectful student of history.

This class exposed me to a lot of Black writings concerning the 19th century. I learned to emphasize voices that are often excluded from history and to consider what absences mean for colonial missions and modern perspectives on the past.

I learned how to think more critically about the construction of history and the role of a historian in curating and imposing silences in the archive. I also developed my secondary and primary source analyses writing skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course was great. Bianca was amazing at facilitating discussions and all of my peers had amazing insight as well. One area of improvement has to do with the structure of the class. I felt like maybe each week could have been organized in a way that each topic built off the next...? sometimes it felt like each week was a separate class almost and the connection to the previous material wasn't emphasized as much.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We had the option to leave our cameras off which was nice. Other than that it was pretty standard and it worked well.

I appreciated that Bianca Dang sent emails each week outlining the expectations and providing online copies of each source within those emails. I think that she also respected individual situations as best she could, which made this class a relief to take during a global pandemic.

Our instructor broke up class time to where a part of it was already made available in a pre recorded lecture. This let us have key information beforehand and allowed us to focus on discussion during class/maximize time. This was also a class that felt truly empathetic to the current time and there was flexibility in work styles and timelines that allowed us space to show up fully and to our best or possible capacity.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This course was fascinating and really teaches you the broad and remarkable history of different types of movements for Black freedom. Bianca is incredible and really brilliant and knowledgeable and also a very kind and understanding teacher.

I definitely would recommend this course. There aren't a lot of courses that take so seriously the notion of freedom and honor black theoretical traditions and movements and this does both with so much intention and cae. It also employs a transnational framework which was really great.
